Code Vein turned out to be a fun and interesting soulslike. I had my eye on it for a long time but never really got around to playing it. Now that I finally did, I had a good time with it.

[h3]What I liked[/h3]

[b]Character editor[/b]
My huge respect. So many options, details and ways to customize your character. You can easily spend hours in it, and that's what I did.

[b]Controls[/b]
Feel responsive and comfortable. They are a bit overloaded with functions, but everything works nicely once you get used to it. Keybinds are customizable, and comfortable for keyboard players. The only annoying thing is having to scroll through consumables manually.

[b]Locations[/b]
They are great both visually and in terms of structure. They feel well thought out and atmospheric.

[b]Bosses[/b]
I played through all bosses solo, without a partner, and it was fun. Learning their attacks and beating them fair and square was super satisfying.

[b]Music[/b]
Really nice. Some tracks are incredibly beautiful and fit the game perfectly.

[h3]What I did not like that much[/h3]

[b]Bugs and technical issues[/b]
Even years after release, the game feels underpolished. I ran into a lot of hitbox problems where attacks just pass through enemies. The target lock can break randomly and send your character swinging in the wrong direction. Also, I had some issues with elevators.

[b]Too many cutscenes[/b]
Some of them feel slow and boring. The characters often say really cliche things. If you have watched at least a couple of teen anime, you have definitely heard it all before.

[b]Enemy variety[/b]
Pretty limited. In the second half of the game they start repeating constantly, and the later areas don't introduce any new enemies at all.

[h3]Final thoughts[/h3]

Overall, the game is good. But it has its flaws. I would rate the game 7 out of 10. I hope the sequel will be even better!

A game highly deserving of a mixed review score, tbh. While I did enjoy my overall experience with the game, I find the later bosses to be incredibly infuriating to the point I almost flipped a coin on whether or not I'd recommend the game. I do think the good outweighs the bad, but as somebody who's been playing soulslikes since 2014, the bad is *bad*. I'm far from the best soulslike player in the world, mind you, but there's a fine line between a skill issue and bad boss design.

     Leaving the boss gripes for a second, I've gotta talk about something I like or the ghost of Juzo Mido's gonna send me to the Cloud District. First off, the Blood Codes. I can't even begin to express how much I enjoy the Blood Code system, which is Code Vein's take on classes. Instead of leveling individual stats like in other soulslikes, your attributes and scaling are determined by your Blood Code. Atlas, for example, focuses on heavier armor and weapons, letting you tank some serious damage. The Prometheus Blood Code, on the other hand, is a glass cannon that hits hard, hits fast, and lets you move fast enough to not get flattened by the frightening abundance of large format women. Each Blood Code also comes with its own abilities, called Gifts, that range from devastating elemental magic to fast and furious melee combos. I do have to gripe about the melee Gifts a little, as there seems to be no added stagger resistance, or enough stagger caused to really justify using them on less durable Blood Codes, but I tend to run light, so that's probably just a skill issue on my end.

     As for more petty gripes, enemy variety is fairly lackluster, and general performance seems to be a little unstable. Not unplayable, but I refuse to believe the FPS counter reading 60 when I'm in particle heavy areas. Weapon and fashion variety is also a bit slim, but the latter is alleviated by the game's character creator. I also personally find destroyed urban environments to be a bit boring as a setting, and there's no escape from crumbling buildings and shattered ruins at any point.

     My last petty gripe, since it's more an issue of my own impatience, but still worth noting - the spike traps in the final area. Let me tell you how much I have come to hate the spike traps since I entered the Provisional Government Center. There are one hundred trillion nerve cells laid in intricate channels throughout the human body. If the word hate was inscribed on each nanoangstrom of those hundred trillion cells, it would not equal one one-billionth of the hate I feel for those spike traps at this micro-instant. hate. HATE.

     As for the major gripe I have with the game, its that the bosses starting with the Successor of the Ribcage about halfway through the game are just not fun to fight. Ribby's second phase has an instakill* attack that she always opens with and sweeps the arena twice, as well as at least two other attacks that can hit you anywhere in the arena. Successor of the Throat has an attack that feels impossible to dodge. The Blade Bearer and Cannoneer are the first and only duo boss in the main path, and I feel like I can say for certainty that Ornstein and Smough doesn't work when Smough has the ability to make you explode from a mile away while Ornstein is freezing you to death with an icy rapier. Juzo FUCKING Mido is not only a boss with a whole laundry list of issues that I could write a whole essay about (for the love of God, ignore that I've already written one), including a distance closing dash with no actual attack that still deals damage, he's voiced by Keith Silverstein, who I'm sure is a very nice man, but I swear to fucking Talos, getting roflstomped by Nazeem for a fucking hour had to be the most infuriated I've been by any boss - no, any SECTION - in any game EVER, and I've played Too Human.

     Bosses after Mido still have all the same issues as previous bosses. Random instakill attacks, attacks with little to no windup (or too much windup for attacks that hit at Mach Jesus), incredibly dodgy hitboxes**, seemingly endless attacks with short cooldowns between different combos, undodgeable AOEs, nearly unpredictable attack patterns, and probably more bullshit that I've already repressed in the couple hours since I've completed my first playthrough.

At the end of the day though, coin flip or no, I'd still lean more towards recommending Code Vein than not. Despite my earlier petty gripe about not liking urban ruins as a setting, the game is still beautiful with a well-defined style, and even the lackluster enemy and equipment variety still provides enough substance to have a good time. Also, Io is best girl, and I will not be accepting any argument, THAT'S THE BOTTOM LINE BECAUSE STONE COLD SAID SO.

*Ribcage's exploding fire laser is an instakill against the Prometheus Blood Code, which is a glass cannon as previously stated. Your mileage may vary, but 2k damage is still 2k damage.
**I have no footage to back this up or I'd be plugging my (dead) YouTube channel, but I swear that the penultimate boss, as well as a few others, were hitting me from at least a foot away with non-AOE attacks.

For a game that really doesn't do anything too compelling, I sure did love it. I bought it at launch on my PS4, bought it again when I got a Series X, then finally landed on the PC version. It is unabashedly anime in a genre that definitely leans into the gritty Western aesthetic, so it stands out in that regard. More than that, it wears its vampire fiction inspirations on its sleeves. The environments aren't great, but the character design is immaculate and sits comfortably between "I wouldn't be shocked to see someone dressed like that in public" and tacti-cool military buff. Given the weird trend of Castlevania cross-over content, I wouldn't be shocked to see Castlevania DLC in the sequel.

But honestly, I can't really tell you that you HAVE to play it. If this is your jam, you already know that by looking at it. The actual substance of the game is a solid Souls-like (even with the jank typical of the genre), but it's a stylish game above all else. The story exists, and there's some cool scenes, but I really couldn't tell you what's going on besides "Not-vampires that are good guys prevent not-vampires that have gone insane from destroying the world." Not that the world is all that great to begin with.

The character progression system, while serviceable, is also not something I would consider a highlight. In the interest of not locking players into a particular build, the game's build system is based primarily around equipment. You do pick up these peculiar little "classes" that tell you what you can and can't equip and grant you skills, and you can master those skills to use with other "classes." But those skills are going to be useless if you don't have the equipment to back them up. You don't assign skill points, you equip cool jackets that buff certain attributes and weaken others. Even if you have a class that will let you use certain skills, the difference between a violent tickle and 2/3rds of an enemy's health bar is whether you equipped the church hoodie or the desert wanderer duster. It's still worth your time to research building your character, and the jackets are pretty slick, so it's not something I'd throw out entirely in the sequel.

Code Vein ‚Ä¶ wow, where to start. This is a game that seems to be equally loved and hated in the souls community, and after spending over 30 hours slogging down its long, repetitive corridors and fighting against the same reskinned enemies over and over again, I came away completely befuddled as to why some people find this game so interesting.

Maybe it‚Äôs the story, which comes off as a ten season anime stuffed into a four-hour info-dump so thick with lore it‚Äôs almost indecipherable to all but the most attentive of players. Anime aficionados might enjoy this, and I certainly like a bit of worldbuilding myself, but when the only way to get most of the exposition is to walk very very slowly through an NPCs memories, it soon becomes boring, especially when you have to do it for the fourteenth or fifteenth time.

The basic premise, if you are interested, is that you are a sexy androgynous vampire that can gain the powers or ‚ÄúBlood Codes‚Äù of others by reliving their memories. The enemies in the game are known as ‚ÄúThe Lost‚Äù, undead that have gone without blood for so long it has driven them mad. Several years ago, a large number of Lost were killed by a woman vampire named Cruz, although the effort drove her into a frenzy and she was consequently killed in turn by her own father.

Things get increasingly complicated from there onwards, with not one by two amnesic characters, a sister with a half-frenzied brother, the obligatory mad-scientist, and, as I‚Äôm sure you can guess, the suspicion Cruz is not quite as dead as everyone thinks (hint : she‚Äôs a vampire).

The game mechanics themselves are incredibly similar to Dark Souls. You go from one zone to the next, finding bonfires and unlocking shortcuts. The only real innovation here is that while you do level up through conventional means, your stats are actually governed by what ‚ÄúBlood Code‚Äù you have picked as these determine things like poise, weapon scaling, and encumbrance among other things. You can switch between these on the fly which allows for a certain amount of flexibility, but, while some players will certainly enjoy its simplicity, I found it far too restrictive. One of the joys of games like Dark Souls is that you can fine-tune your build to fit your playstyle and I never really found a way to do that effectively here.

For example, as a fan of strength builds, I quickly gravitated towards the Atlas Code that allowed me to wear heavy armour and wield big swords at the cost of movement and dodge speed. Thing is, I like having a great sword and being able to dodge, which is impossible from the get-go here, I had to learn all the skills from the Atlas Code, then switch to a different Code and learn all the skills from there, none of which was fun.

I wouldn‚Äôt mind suffering through all that if the combat was fast and addictive. Unfortunately, it‚Äôs neither, with an over-reliance of you getting swarmed by enemies that stun-lock you or knock you out of your attack animation mid-swing. I found the moveset to be really finicky too, especially the running attack which sometimes ended with an overhead swing and sometimes with a thrust attack, and I‚Äôm still not sure why. Your heavy attacks do the most amount of damage, but I ended up abandoning these entirely after realising they are constantly interrupted and that two or three light attacks do as much damage and fill my ichor (magic points) roughly the same amount.

Finally, I‚Äôve carefully avoided talking about the jiggle physics here, but even without diving into the waifu aspect of the game, you have to admit that having characters run through the snow fields and ice lakes of one of the levels dressed in what basically amounts to a bra and panties is maybe a little underdressed. Or I guess vampires just don‚Äôt feel the cold?

I don‚Äôt despise anime by any stretch of the imagination, I just don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs a great fit for a soulslike, and the cumbersome way Bandai Namco has chosen to doll out its story beats just doesn‚Äôt work. The Blood Code system was an interesting idea that failed to grip me either, as I disliked not having sufficient control over my character‚Äôs growth. If neither of these things bother you then maybe give Code Vein a try, but I myself find it difficult to recommend.

Review after playing through the game, which took about 30 hours.  There's stuff in this game about anime vampires that some people will like.  But I think its overall pretty mid and your time would be better spent playing something else.

[h2] The Good [/h2]
The callout nice feature of this game is how easy it is to switch between builds.  You collect 'blood codes' of other characters in the game which give you their move-set while equipped.  After spending enough time with those abilities you unlock them permanently and can apply them while using other codes to make a really diverse set of builds.  Swapping between codes is a really quick process, technically you could swap builds for every fight.  Going from full caster to a full strength build takes a few seconds, and that is really neat.  Its also a bit tiring trying to level and manage all of that, but I'm sure some people are really into that.

Exploration is also pretty well done.  This isn't open world but it is still satisfying.  

The story is entertaining enough.  The game does stop every time you get or try to upgrade a blood code to force you to walk through someone's memory.  That's sort of a pace killer imo, but yeah the story is present and not quite what I was expecting from the premise.

[h2] The Rest of It [/h2]
I didn't enjoy the combat, it felt too loose for me.  And that is kind of the focus of the game.  They did try some things around, like having your parry timing change based on the armor you are wearing.  I applaud the attempt, but I found the parry window ranges from "Early" to "Really Really Early" so I just didn't engage with that system after a while.

It feels like they designed this game to be a multiplayer game, but then backed down to giving you a companion all the time.  So a lot of the time it felt like they maybe should have put more effort into balancing out enemy attack windows and such, but instead just band-aided the problem with an AI buddy.  

And that laziness extends to a feature I was looking forward to, the Depths.  Which is a repeatable dungeon with a farmable boss at the end.  Those unfortunately feel like a reskin/copy&paste job that I just lost interest in after doing about 5 of them.

I also encountered at least 3 game ending bugs.  2 were freeze ups and one was a hard crash during a memory.  It was weird because I didn't notice small glitches, other than my AI companion dodge rolling nothing over and over again in a corner.

[h2] So in Conclusion [/h2]
The game is okay, but IMO you may enjoy yourself more playing something else.  I think the thing I enjoyed most about this was the really big sale I bought it on.

I saw this game through to the end, and I can't summarize it any other way than that, for five bucks, I felt like I ultimately had wasted my time.

[h2] We have Dark Souls at home[/h2] 
Let's get the obvious one out of the way. Yeah, the Dark Souls DNA is in there, but more reminiscent of a disappointment of a child. Everything that's borrowed from the genre is done Okay at best, and frustratingly poor at worst.

In fact, I had to ask myself this question: Would this game even pass 'mediocre' if it didn't have all the Dark Souls stuff? The answer's no. This slap-dash attempt at it really is what's keeping this game from truly falling into the abyss, and it's not even doing a good job at it.

This is where the character limit for steam reviews really hurts, because I could spend the next hour going through the list. So instead I'll summarize it as this: If this is your first entry in Soulslikes, turn back and get a refund. There are only attempts at copying the genius that took place in the legendary series, and none of them are done with any understanding of why they worked.

[h2]I fear the Anime fan who's okay with swallowing this quality of storytelling[/h2]

Can... can I speak plainly to you for a second? You know that stereotypical anime vibe, with those stereotypical beats of "I'm with you!" "You'll never get away with this, bad guy!" "Thank you for being there for me" while being literally a silent protagonist for 99.8% of the game? Just imagine the most trite stuff, stereotypical villains with evil laughs that don't sound good. It's just so... stereotypical japanese tripe. There is nothing new, ingenious or worthwhile here. If I watched this as a cutscene movie to save myself the 24 hours, I'd still feel like I'd wasted my time.

[h3]Alright, here goes.[/h3]

You are special Vampy McVampire, in a world of mostly vampires (read: Revenants) who need blood beads (glass blood... thingies, because biting people is yucky!). There once was a really, really strong and evil vampire called the Queen! So strong that they couldn't kill her, so they just split up her heart in pieces, and put them in Successors.
But these Successors will eventually give into frenzy within their self-imposed prison, and hurt everybody! Luckily, you can eat the Queen's pieces with no repercussion! You even get classes out of it! So let's go kill/save all the Successors, beat the badguy who has such a stereotypical evolution monologue, it made me genuinely wish for Albert Wesker's sultry voice.

Really, it's the endings that bother me the greatest in this. Or rather, the mechanics regarding your choice of them. There's three endings, good/normal/bad. You get the good ending by finding all the... 'vessel pieces' of the relevant Successor, beating them, and then instead of letting them turn to ash you 'save' them by giving them their sanity back or something.

[b]Fun fact[/b]: The game never explains any of this. You're never told that you have to turn every map inside out for all the pieces and merge them for memories (read: forced walking Fallout 4 memory lane setpieces) with the Successor's attendant BEFORE you ever start the fight. Attendants are... big titted white hair girls that all look the same and the one that's assigned to you has an existential crisis, but nobody cares about that.

Anyway, if you mess up saving even ONE Successor, the Good ending's locked out. Yeah, get rekt, idiot. Save none of them, and you get the bad ending. So if you're unaware of this system and accidentally saved one and didn't another, guess what: You're locked in the 'normal' ending. Remember how in the Souls games you had to go out of your way to 'earn' the endings? Code Vein missed that tidbit, and is so much worse for it. All these successors have emotional connections to your companions, and you've failed them, but they still thank you for trying, because you're the protag!

That's where I give up.

[h2]Unsurprisingly, it's the builds that kept me interested[/h2]

Classes are called Blood Codes, and there's a heaping helping of them that you can freely switch between at any time outside of combat. They all sit somewhere on a venn diagram that governs combat styles, the most prominent stats, gift power (read: skills, like spells and special attacks that require ichor (read: mana points)) and so on.

They all also have their own set of skills unique to them, most of which you have to unlock by finding their relevant vessel pieces and then purchasing them with the currency that's like souls but I forgot the name of. You've got 8 active slots and 4 passive slots, and when you beat enough enemies with them equipped, they become 'mastered' and usable on any of the other classes.

Honestly? Great idea. It's a very different (maybe even unique?) take on spells and attack skills and I'm here for it. Making builds is one of my favorite delights in gaming, and you're going to have a huge load of them to choose from as you go.

Downside though: If a particular blood code does not jive for you in how it (doesn't) compliments your combat, you're either going to annoy yourself enough to level it up, ignore it, or use a currency + souls to unlock the skill immediately. Said currency is rather unreliable to farm and has an absolutely uninspired name. Like Awake MJ018 and Awake MJ212. What's that even supposed to mean? You couldn't have just given it a name like, Small Awakening Stone, Medium, etc. or something? So dumb.

[h2]The combat's there, I guess[/h2]

The combat constantly flows between "I've done this a million times", and constant annoyance. There's five weapon classes, with movesets differing within the class, from slightly to completely. Not a terrible idea, be boring if there was no variety. I'm partial towards the one halberd that's all spear thrusts. Quick and damaging. The greatswords're good fun too.

The 1h swords felt... spammy and underpowered, the 'bayonet' (which is actually the gun AND the bayonet attached to the front) is your quickest and dash-iest 'long dagger' with a pinch of using Ichor to shoot a moderately powerful bullet as a heavy attack. And the hammer is... like a slower, less interesting greatsword, honestly.

Where it rattles apart is when you go up against enemies that are relentless and love exploiting their moveset.
A mist-dash that closest the gap immediately, even across the map, AND ignores block? You bet they'll pressure you with it!
Take full damage on the end of a wide swing while sitting behind the enemy.
Get stunlocked when ganged up by monkeys, taking you from full to zero in mere seconds.

It feels like, just because you're given the option of an AI companion, that the game has the A-Ok to pound you into the ground at any moment.

Speaking of which, you bet the AI companions swim between 'useless b*stard' and Unga Bunga. Yakumo's great because he can spam a skill on you that soaks up the next hit you take for 95%, and unga bunga's his greatsword onto the enemy. Great for bosses. Everyone else is kind of situational, based on how much ranged support you need in your map traversal.

[h2]I'm tired, man.[/h2]

We're sitting at this frustrating situation where the potential is there with a few good ideas, only to be marred by a series of either bad choices or low effort. You can't argue that the game's not wasting my time when one of the ways you have me transition to the next area is literally a 5 minute uneventful concrete hallway with the occasional ladder and nothing else to look at, not even enemies! And one of the sidequest NPCs has her smack dab in it! Because yes, I love spending minutes looking at my stamina bar drop to zero as I sprint through.

For as much as I complained about them, at least Evil West had [i]some[/i] satisfying combat, and Remnant 1&2 took a shot at the genre by trying to fit mostly shooting into it. And those games still sucked!

Code Vein ‚Ä¶ wow, where to start. This is a game that seems to be equally loved and hated in the souls community, and after spending over 30 hours slogging down its long, repetitive corridors and fighting against the same reskinned enemies over and over again, I came away completely befuddled as to why some people find this game so interesting.

Maybe it‚Äôs the story, which comes off as a ten season anime stuffed into a four-hour info-dump so thick with lore it‚Äôs almost indecipherable to all but the most attentive of players. Anime aficionados might enjoy this, and I certainly like a bit of worldbuilding myself, but when the only way to get most of the exposition is to walk very very slowly through an NPCs memories, it soon becomes boring, especially when you have to do it for the fourteenth or fifteenth time.

The basic premise, if you are interested, is that you are a sexy androgynous vampire that can gain the powers or ‚ÄúBlood Codes‚Äù of others by reliving their memories. The enemies in the game are known as ‚ÄúThe Lost‚Äù, undead that have gone without blood for so long it has driven them mad. Several years ago, a large number of Lost were killed by a woman vampire named Cruz, although the effort drove her into a frenzy and she was consequently killed in turn by her own father.

Things get increasingly complicated from there onwards, with not one by two amnesic characters, a sister with a half-frenzied brother, the obligatory mad-scientist, and, as I‚Äôm sure you can guess, the suspicion Cruz is not quite as dead as everyone thinks (hint : she‚Äôs a vampire).

The game mechanics themselves are incredibly similar to Dark Souls. You go from one zone to the next, finding bonfires and unlocking shortcuts. The only real innovation here is that while you do level up through conventional means, your stats are actually governed by what ‚ÄúBlood Code‚Äù you have picked as these determine things like poise, weapon scaling, and encumbrance among other things. You can switch between these on the fly which allows for a certain amount of flexibility, but, while some players will certainly enjoy its simplicity, I found it far too restrictive. One of the joys of games like Dark Souls is that you can fine-tune your build to fit your playstyle and I never really found a way to do that effectively here.

For example, as a fan of strength builds, I quickly gravitated towards the Atlas Code that allowed me to wear heavy armour and wield big swords at the cost of movement and dodge speed. Thing is, I like having a great sword and being able to dodge, which is impossible from the get-go here, I had to learn all the skills from the Atlas Code, then switch to a different Code and learn all the skills from there, none of which was fun.

I wouldn‚Äôt mind suffering through all that if the combat was fast and addictive. Unfortunately, it‚Äôs neither, with an over-reliance of you getting swarmed by enemies that stun-lock you or knock you out of your attack animation mid-swing. I found the moveset to be really finicky too, especially the running attack which sometimes ended with an overhead swing and sometimes with a thrust attack, and I‚Äôm still not sure why. Your heavy attacks do the most amount of damage, but I ended up abandoning these entirely after realising they are constantly interrupted and that two or three light attacks do as much damage and fill my ichor (magic points) roughly the same amount.

Finally, I‚Äôve carefully avoided talking about the jiggle physics here, but even without diving into the waifu aspect of the game, you have to admit that having characters run through the snow fields and ice lakes of one of the levels dressed in what basically amounts to a bra and panties is maybe a little underdressed. Or I guess vampires just don‚Äôt feel the cold?

I don‚Äôt despise anime by any stretch of the imagination, I just don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs a great fit for a soulslike, and the cumbersome way Bandai Namco has chosen to doll out its story beats just doesn‚Äôt work. The Blood Code system was an interesting idea that failed to grip me either, as I disliked not having sufficient control over my character‚Äôs growth. If neither of these things bother you then maybe give Code Vein a try, but I myself find it difficult to recommend.

Review after playing through the game, which took about 30 hours.  There's stuff in this game about anime vampires that some people will like.  But I think its overall pretty mid and your time would be better spent playing something else.

[h2] The Good [/h2]
The callout nice feature of this game is how easy it is to switch between builds.  You collect 'blood codes' of other characters in the game which give you their move-set while equipped.  After spending enough time with those abilities you unlock them permanently and can apply them while using other codes to make a really diverse set of builds.  Swapping between codes is a really quick process, technically you could swap builds for every fight.  Going from full caster to a full strength build takes a few seconds, and that is really neat.  Its also a bit tiring trying to level and manage all of that, but I'm sure some people are really into that.

Exploration is also pretty well done.  This isn't open world but it is still satisfying.  

The story is entertaining enough.  The game does stop every time you get or try to upgrade a blood code to force you to walk through someone's memory.  That's sort of a pace killer imo, but yeah the story is present and not quite what I was expecting from the premise.

[h2] The Rest of It [/h2]
I didn't enjoy the combat, it felt too loose for me.  And that is kind of the focus of the game.  They did try some things around, like having your parry timing change based on the armor you are wearing.  I applaud the attempt, but I found the parry window ranges from "Early" to "Really Really Early" so I just didn't engage with that system after a while.

It feels like they designed this game to be a multiplayer game, but then backed down to giving you a companion all the time.  So a lot of the time it felt like they maybe should have put more effort into balancing out enemy attack windows and such, but instead just band-aided the problem with an AI buddy.  

And that laziness extends to a feature I was looking forward to, the Depths.  Which is a repeatable dungeon with a farmable boss at the end.  Those unfortunately feel like a reskin/copy&paste job that I just lost interest in after doing about 5 of them.

I also encountered at least 3 game ending bugs.  2 were freeze ups and one was a hard crash during a memory.  It was weird because I didn't notice small glitches, other than my AI companion dodge rolling nothing over and over again in a corner.

[h2] So in Conclusion [/h2]
The game is okay, but IMO you may enjoy yourself more playing something else.  I think the thing I enjoyed most about this was the really big sale I bought it on.

I saw this game through to the end, and I can't summarize it any other way than that, for five bucks, I felt like I ultimately had wasted my time.

[h2] We have Dark Souls at home[/h2] 
Let's get the obvious one out of the way. Yeah, the Dark Souls DNA is in there, but more reminiscent of a disappointment of a child. Everything that's borrowed from the genre is done Okay at best, and frustratingly poor at worst.

In fact, I had to ask myself this question: Would this game even pass 'mediocre' if it didn't have all the Dark Souls stuff? The answer's no. This slap-dash attempt at it really is what's keeping this game from truly falling into the abyss, and it's not even doing a good job at it.

This is where the character limit for steam reviews really hurts, because I could spend the next hour going through the list. So instead I'll summarize it as this: If this is your first entry in Soulslikes, turn back and get a refund. There are only attempts at copying the genius that took place in the legendary series, and none of them are done with any understanding of why they worked.

[h2]I fear the Anime fan who's okay with swallowing this quality of storytelling[/h2]

Can... can I speak plainly to you for a second? You know that stereotypical anime vibe, with those stereotypical beats of "I'm with you!" "You'll never get away with this, bad guy!" "Thank you for being there for me" while being literally a silent protagonist for 99.8% of the game? Just imagine the most trite stuff, stereotypical villains with evil laughs that don't sound good. It's just so... stereotypical japanese tripe. There is nothing new, ingenious or worthwhile here. If I watched this as a cutscene movie to save myself the 24 hours, I'd still feel like I'd wasted my time.

[h3]Alright, here goes.[/h3]

You are special Vampy McVampire, in a world of mostly vampires (read: Revenants) who need blood beads (glass blood... thingies, because biting people is yucky!). There once was a really, really strong and evil vampire called the Queen! So strong that they couldn't kill her, so they just split up her heart in pieces, and put them in Successors.
But these Successors will eventually give into frenzy within their self-imposed prison, and hurt everybody! Luckily, you can eat the Queen's pieces with no repercussion! You even get classes out of it! So let's go kill/save all the Successors, beat the badguy who has such a stereotypical evolution monologue, it made me genuinely wish for Albert Wesker's sultry voice.

Really, it's the endings that bother me the greatest in this. Or rather, the mechanics regarding your choice of them. There's three endings, good/normal/bad. You get the good ending by finding all the... 'vessel pieces' of the relevant Successor, beating them, and then instead of letting them turn to ash you 'save' them by giving them their sanity back or something.

[b]Fun fact[/b]: The game never explains any of this. You're never told that you have to turn every map inside out for all the pieces and merge them for memories (read: forced walking Fallout 4 memory lane setpieces) with the Successor's attendant BEFORE you ever start the fight. Attendants are... big titted white hair girls that all look the same and the one that's assigned to you has an existential crisis, but nobody cares about that.

Anyway, if you mess up saving even ONE Successor, the Good ending's locked out. Yeah, get rekt, idiot. Save none of them, and you get the bad ending. So if you're unaware of this system and accidentally saved one and didn't another, guess what: You're locked in the 'normal' ending. Remember how in the Souls games you had to go out of your way to 'earn' the endings? Code Vein missed that tidbit, and is so much worse for it. All these successors have emotional connections to your companions, and you've failed them, but they still thank you for trying, because you're the protag!

That's where I give up.

[h2]Unsurprisingly, it's the builds that kept me interested[/h2]

Classes are called Blood Codes, and there's a heaping helping of them that you can freely switch between at any time outside of combat. They all sit somewhere on a venn diagram that governs combat styles, the most prominent stats, gift power (read: skills, like spells and special attacks that require ichor (read: mana points)) and so on.

They all also have their own set of skills unique to them, most of which you have to unlock by finding their relevant vessel pieces and then purchasing them with the currency that's like souls but I forgot the name of. You've got 8 active slots and 4 passive slots, and when you beat enough enemies with them equipped, they become 'mastered' and usable on any of the other classes.

Honestly? Great idea. It's a very different (maybe even unique?) take on spells and attack skills and I'm here for it. Making builds is one of my favorite delights in gaming, and you're going to have a huge load of them to choose from as you go.

Downside though: If a particular blood code does not jive for you in how it (doesn't) compliments your combat, you're either going to annoy yourself enough to level it up, ignore it, or use a currency + souls to unlock the skill immediately. Said currency is rather unreliable to farm and has an absolutely uninspired name. Like Awake MJ018 and Awake MJ212. What's that even supposed to mean? You couldn't have just given it a name like, Small Awakening Stone, Medium, etc. or something? So dumb.

[h2]The combat's there, I guess[/h2]

The combat constantly flows between "I've done this a million times", and constant annoyance. There's five weapon classes, with movesets differing within the class, from slightly to completely. Not a terrible idea, be boring if there was no variety. I'm partial towards the one halberd that's all spear thrusts. Quick and damaging. The greatswords're good fun too.

The 1h swords felt... spammy and underpowered, the 'bayonet' (which is actually the gun AND the bayonet attached to the front) is your quickest and dash-iest 'long dagger' with a pinch of using Ichor to shoot a moderately powerful bullet as a heavy attack. And the hammer is... like a slower, less interesting greatsword, honestly.

Where it rattles apart is when you go up against enemies that are relentless and love exploiting their moveset.
A mist-dash that closest the gap immediately, even across the map, AND ignores block? You bet they'll pressure you with it!
Take full damage on the end of a wide swing while sitting behind the enemy.
Get stunlocked when ganged up by monkeys, taking you from full to zero in mere seconds.

It feels like, just because you're given the option of an AI companion, that the game has the A-Ok to pound you into the ground at any moment.

Speaking of which, you bet the AI companions swim between 'useless b*stard' and Unga Bunga. Yakumo's great because he can spam a skill on you that soaks up the next hit you take for 95%, and unga bunga's his greatsword onto the enemy. Great for bosses. Everyone else is kind of situational, based on how much ranged support you need in your map traversal.

[h2]I'm tired, man.[/h2]

We're sitting at this frustrating situation where the potential is there with a few good ideas, only to be marred by a series of either bad choices or low effort. You can't argue that the game's not wasting my time when one of the ways you have me transition to the next area is literally a 5 minute uneventful concrete hallway with the occasional ladder and nothing else to look at, not even enemies! And one of the sidequest NPCs has her smack dab in it! Because yes, I love spending minutes looking at my stamina bar drop to zero as I sprint through.

For as much as I complained about them, at least Evil West had [i]some[/i] satisfying combat, and Remnant 1&2 took a shot at the genre by trying to fit mostly shooting into it. And those games still sucked!

While the character customization is impressive and the art style appealing, the combat often feels clunky and inconsistent, lacking the precision and satisfaction expected from the genre. Level design is repetitive, enemy AI is erratic, and the story, despite some interesting ideas, quickly loses momentum. The result is a game that looks stylish but rarely feels engaging, more imitation than innovation.
